overview.title: Dashboard Mosqlimate
overview.subtitle: Explore, compare and evaluate forecasts generated by different forecasting models registered on the Mosqlimate platform.

general.title: General
general.description: General dashboard exploration area, where it is possible to view and compare forecasts produced by different models available on the platform.
general.what_is_displayed_description: Forecasts, observed data, and error metrics comparing predicted values with observed data.
general.scale_description: municipal, state or national, depending on the models submitted.
general.goal_description: compare the performance and behavior of the models using the following error metrics: Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS), interval score, Weighted Interval Score (WIS).
questions: How close are the predictions to the observed data?
How does behavior vary between regions?

imdc.title: IMDC
imdc.description: Visualization dedicated to forecasts produced in the context of the
imdc.models_description: only models participating in the challenge.
imdc.goal_description: evaluate and compare the challenge forecasts using the following error metrics: Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS), interval score and Weighted Interval Score (WIS).
questions: How do the IMDC models compare to each other?
Which forecasts best anticipate peaks in cases?
How do the models perform throughout the season?

infodengue.title: Mosquito-borne Diseases
infodengue.description: This endpoint gives access to data from the Infodengue project, which provide a number of epidemiological variables for all the Brazilian municipalities on a weekly time scale. The request parameters and data variables are described below.

variables.casos_est: Estimated number of cases per week using the nowcasting model
variables.casos_est_min: 95% credibility interval of the estimated number of cases
variables.casos: Number of notified cases per week (values are retrospectively updated every week)
variables.p_inc100k: Estimated incidence rate (cases per pop x 100.00)
variables.nivel: Alert level (1 = green, 2 = yellow, 3 = orange, 4 = red)
variables.Rt: Point estimate of the reproductive number of cases
variables.receptivo: Indicates climate receptivity, i.e., conditions for high vectorial capacity. 0 = unfavorable, 1 = favorable, 2 = favorable this week and last week, 3 = favorable for at least three weeks
variables.transmissao: Evidence of sustained transmission: 0 = no evidence, 1 = possible, 2 = likely, 3 = highly likely
variables.nivel_inc: Estimated incidence below pre-epidemic threshold, 1 = above pre-epidemic threshold but below epidemic threshold, 2 = above epidemic threshold
variables.umidmax: Average daily maximum humidity percentages along the week
variables.umidmed: Average daily humidity percentages along the week
variables.umidmin: Average daily minimum humidity percentages along the week
variables.tempmax: Average daily maximum temperatures along the week
variables.tempmed: Average daily temperatures along the week
variables.tempmin: Average daily minimum temperatures along the week
variables.casprov: Probable number of cases per week (cases - discarded cases)
variables.casprov_est: Probable number of estimated cases per week
variables.casprov_est_min: Credibility interval of the probable number of cases
variables.casprov_est_max: Credibility interval of the probable number of cases
variables.casconf: Cases effectively confirmed with laboratory testing

climate.title: Climate data
climate.description: Through this API endpoint, you can fetch several climate variables that have been extracted for all brazilian municipalities from the satellite-based reanalysis data provided by Copernicus ERA5.

mosquito.title: Mosquito Egg Count
mosquito.description: Here you get access to mosquito abundance data from the Contaovos project, co-developed by the Mosqlimate project. These data, described below, are based on eggtraps distributed throughout Brasil according to a monitoring design specified by the Ministry of Health.

episcanner.title: EpiScanner Data
episcanner.description: Real-time Epidemic Scanner data providing estimates of epidemiological parameters for cities in Brazil.

variables.peak_week: Estimated epidemiological week of the epidemic peak
variables.ep_ini: Estimated starting week of the epidemic (YYYYWW)
variables.ep_end: Estimated ending week of the epidemic (YYYYWW)
variables.ep_dur: Estimated duration of the epidemic in weeks

publications.title: Scientific Production
publications.subtitle: A collection of our academic contributions, datasets, and software developments.

team.flavio: PI of the Mosqlimate and associate professor at the School of Applied Mathematics at FGV, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. I am also part of the GRAPH network, based at the University of Geneva, where I am their data analysis coordinator. In Brazil, I am also one of the coordinators of the Infodengue project. My research interests revolve around the epidemiology of Infectious diseases from the point of view of math, statistics, and data science.
team.leonardo: Public health researcher at the Scientific Computing Program (PROCC), Oswaldo Cruz Foundation (Fiocruz). He is a research fellow at FAPERJ and CNPq. His main research is on developing and applying (Bayesian) statistical methods for infectious disease epidemiology. He is a co-lead on WP2.
team.luiz: Assistant Professor at the School of Applied Mathematics, Getulio Vargas Foundation. His interests are in Biostatistics, particularly Markov chain Monte Carlo, statistical phylogenetics, and model combination. He co-led on WP2, hoping to bring state-of-the-art model comparison and combination techniques to predict arboviral diseases.
team.leon: Professor at CEFET, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Developer of the Conta Ovos application, which aims to monitor the density of Aedes aegypti eggs in space and time. My interests are in image processing and application design. WP1 Coordinator.
team.eduardo: Bachelor's in control and automation engineering at UTFPR. He has experience in analyzing public health data and developing machine learning models applied to epidemiological contexts. His interests include data science applied to health, mathematical and computational modeling of diseases, development of tools in Python, and interdisciplinary collaboration in social impact projects. He works as a data scientist in the WP2 of the Mosqlimate project. He is also Mosqlimate project manager.
team.iasmim: Postdoctoral researcher at FGV EMAp. PhD and Master's in Public Health Epidemiology from ENSP/FIOCRUZ. Researcher at the Infodengue project and Mosqlimate, she is a researcher at the WP2, where she works with models involving arbovirus transmission patterns and their epidemiological and climatic determinants. She is also Mosqlimate’s Community Engagement Manager and lead researcher at WP3. Her research interests focus on communicable diseases and their epidemiology.
team.lua: Computer Science student and Open Source enthusiast. Software Developer at Getulio Vargas Foundation, responsible for the development, deployment and maintenance of Mosqlimate's Project.
team.lucas: Statistician and data scientist, holding a PhD in Epidemiology in Public Health from ENSP/FIOCRUZ. My professional experience includes applying statistical and machine learning methodologies to diverse fields such as agriculture and healthcare, as well as contributing to public health initiatives and data analysis for international organizations.
team.fabiana: A master's and a doctorate in Epidemiology and Public Health from Universidade de Brasília and Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona. She is a postdoctoral researcher at FGV EMAp and a member of the Mosqlimate Team, researching dengue surveillance strategies and the relationship between socioeconomic, climatic, and environmental factors with arboviral diseases. Fabiana is Mosqlimate’s Forecast Sprint coordinator, managing our annual International forecasting competitions.
team.beatriz: Postdoctoral researcher at FGV EMAp and a member of the Mosqlimate Team doing research on Bayesian inference, Mathematical modeling of Dengue fever, and Possibility Theory. Holds a master's and a Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics from the University of Campinas. She is curious about hybrid models of infectious diseases involving dynamical fuzzy systems, neural networks, and statistical methods of uncertainty quantification.
team.marcio: Physics PhD candidate, holds a profound affinity for dynamic systems, statistical mechanics, Bayesian inference, and machine learning. Currently contributing his insights as a collaborative researcher to the Mosqlimate project.
team.davi: Postdoctoral researcher at FGV EMAp and a member of the Mosqlimate Team, where he focuses on dengue forecasting using machine learning and optimal transport methods within spatio-temporal modelling. Holds a PhD in Applied Mathematics and Data Science from FGV EMAp.
team.julie: Postdoctoral researcher at FGV EMAp. She is an applied mathematician, physicist, and data scientist with a PhD in Applied Mathematics and Data Science. She holds a master’s and a bachelor’s degree in Physics. Her research focuses on mathematical modeling of epidemics, emphasizing using epidemiological model-informed neural networks (PINNs) to capture complex dengue dynamics. She also has expertise in machine learning, causal inference, and developing data pipelines for epidemiological analysis. Her work seeks to integrate advanced computing and artificial intelligence methods for understanding and controlling infectious diseases.
team.ana: Undergraduate student in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence at FGV-EMAp. She works as a developer and data scientist on the Mosqlimate research project. FAPERJ undergraduate research fellow in a project carried out by Fiocruz researchers with 15 girls from public schools in Rio de Janeiro. Interest in data science applied to health, machine learning and social projects, especially those related to education.
team.ezequiel: Master's student in Applied Mathematics and Data Science at FGV EMAp. His work focuses on Bayesian modeling, particularly in power priors. He currently serves as a research assistant on the hdbayes R package project and Mosqlimate. His primary research interests lie in biostatistics, especially in Bayesian and computational statistics.
team.zuilho: Undergraduate student in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence at FGV EMAp. I'm particularly interested in Machine Learning and Reinforcement Learning. Currently, I'm working on reinforcement learning models where agents are designed to optimize testing distribution for arboviral diseases such as dengue and chikungunya across different regions.
team.sillas: Undergraduate student in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence at FGV-EMAp. He is currently working on integrating an AI assistant into the Mosqlimate platform. His interests focus on Machine Learning, particularly Deep Learning models.
team.raquel: Marie Curie fellow at the Barcelona Supercomputing Center in the Global Health Resilience group. Her background is in quantitative epidemiology and her research focuses on infectious disease dynamics and their association with environmental, climate, and social factors. She is a collaborator in the Mosqlimate project.
team.thais: Biologist with a MSc and PhD in Zoology. I am interested in studies on ecology and population dynamics of arbovirus vectors and their impact on the dynamics of disease transmission. I currently work as an analyst at the Epidemiological Intelligence Center of the Secretariat of Health of Rio de Janeiro City and as a collaborating researcher in the Infodengue system.
team.lais: Researcher at the Scientific Computing Program (PROCC/Fiocruz), with a master's and PhD in Epidemiology from ENSP/Fiocruz. She completed postdoctoral training at PROCC and CReSP, Université de Montréal. Her work focuses on Bayesian modeling of infectious diseases, especially arboviruses, analyzing spatial patterns and socio-environmental determinants.
team.bruno: Postdoctoral researcher at the Barcelona Supercomputing Center in the Global Health Resilience group, where he develops infectious disease models for early warning and decision support. He builds indicators to track the impacts of climate change on health using open-access and reproducible digital toolkits. He is a biologist, PhD in Ecology and Evolution, and MSc in Parasitology. As a collaborator in Mosqlimate, Bruno is developing deep learning models to predict dengue in Brazil using data from the Infodengue system.
team.joyce: PhD student in Applied Mathematics and Data Science at FGV EMAp. She holds a master’s degree in Mathematical Modeling of Information and a bachelor’s degree in Applied Mathematics. Her research interests lie in mathematical modeling of complex systems, with a particular focus on epidemiological dynamics and data-driven approaches to understanding real-world phenomena. She is interested in integrating quantitative modeling, data analysis, and computational methods to support decision-making in public health contexts.

hero.title: Mosqlimate
hero.subtitle: Intelligent Surveillance of Arboviruses and Climate

project.title: About the project
project.description: Mosqlimate is an innovative platform for monitoring and forecasting risks related to arboviruses (diseases transmitted by mosquitoes) in the context of climate change. We develop tools that integrate climate, epidemiological, and entomological data to improve early outbreak detection and support control strategies in Brazil and South America. Our purpose is to prevent risks and strengthen the response to diseases like dengue, chikungunya, and Zika.

data.title: Explore our data
data.cases_desc: Weekly data on dengue, Zika, and chikungunya for all Brazilian municipalities to track trends and seasonality for disease control.
data.climate_desc: Daily climate variables extracted from satellite reanalysis data, such as temperature and precipitation, to predict the proliferation dynamics of vector mosquitoes.
data.mosquito_desc: Data from the Contaovos project, obtained through traps for Aedes aegypti eggs to monitor vector density in real-time in Brazil.
data.epi_desc: Analyzes and presents updated data on the expansion of dengue, Zika, and chikungunya in the national territory, focusing on spatial and temporal transmission patterns.

models.title: Analyze our models
models.description: Mosqlimate provides and registers forecasting models for dengue, chikungunya, and Zika, using official public domain climatic and epidemiological data. These models allow for methodology comparison through dashboards, improved forecasts, and identification of expansion signs or outbreaks, including new arboviruses, integrating with the Infodengue early warning system.
models.image_message: Click to be redirected to the Models tab.

differentials.title: Discover Mosqlimate's differentials
differentials.integration_desc: Gathers epidemiological, climatic, and entomological information in one place.
differentials.comparison_desc: Dynamic visualizations that allow comparing predictions from different models.
differentials.team_desc: Epidemiologists, data scientists, biologists, statisticians, and physicists ensuring innovative analyses.
differentials.quality_desc: Updated content, supported by scientific publications and validated results.
differentials.community_desc: Holds prominent events such as the biannual E-Vigilância and the annual Sprint, in addition to continuous seminars.

team.title: Meet our team
team.image_message: Click to be redirected to the 'About Us' tab.
